Comment: With idldice81's permission I'm annotating this game for the benefit of our team, the Burninators.
This opening is known as Petrov's Defence (C42).
This opening is known as Petrov's Defence (C42).
This opening is known as Petrov's Defence (C42).
And now the French attack variant.
The standard continuation is unfolding...
This is now the classical attack variant, all moves according to book.
This is now the classical attack variant, all moves according to book.
This is now the classical attack variant, all moves according to book.

This move is designed to stake a claim to the center and post my knight to be a constant thorn in white's side.  An early priority should be to dislodge my knight or attack the d5 pawn, all while developing your own pieces.
Book response.
Book, and for those chess monkeys, it's called the Marshall variation.
Castling is a good idea here as it frees up the rook to play as well.
This move was designed to give my knight and the d5 pawn some staying power.  I anticipated that his c pawn of remaining knight will come into play soon.
And there it is.  This is a great move as it puts pressure on my d pawn but also allows his knight to develop as well, to bring on the heat.  There are a lot of good possibilities here for white.
Time to castle in case I need to bring my rook into the game.
This is one of the most typical responses at this point and white is attacking just like he should.
No other response worth considering.
Continuing an aggressive attack, white is in good shape.  I have a few options here.

This was perhaps not my strongest play, but I wanted to put some pressure on white's knight and see what shook loose.  I also didn't want to give white the chance to shift another pawn to his center, giving him a stronger center advantage.  My d pawn is weak and isolated, but if it is, I'd rather his was too.

If white takes Nxd5, Bxh2+ regains parity.
Effectively earning a pawn advantage.
No other choice.
And now white is ahead a pawn.  I have only a few responses that can save me from real damage on my queenside rook.
I prefer this move to Qc7 as it continues development, but also puts some added pressure on his d pawn, and maybe something good can happen.  So far white is playing superb.
